title.narrative: 7. Mine Action and Cluster Munitions Programme 2016 -2020

description.narrative: For the community members living close to the minefields: a) immediate improvement in human security through removal of the threat, reducing to zero the potential for future violent injury; b) improvement in economic livelihood opportunities through releasing fallow agricultural land on which crops can be grown. For sustainable peace and stability in the West Bank: c) potential access to source of explosives is denied through safe removal of mines and ordnance; d) effective humanitarian mine action, jointly coordinated by INMAA and PMAC encourages dialogue between Israeli and Palestinian entities, in particular strengthening capacity and credibility of a PA institution.

Funding from the Netherlands Government and diplomatic support through the Representative Office in Ramallah and the Embassy in Tel Aviv played an important role in helping establish the HALO West Bank programme in 2012. The first clearance took place in April 2014. Israeli mandated Quality Assurance of all programme clearance is entirely funded by the United States. Support through this grant sends a relevant message of continued Netherlands commitment to impacted Palestinian communities.

The HALO West Bank programme is funded to remove the threat of mines and UXO from nine minefields in the Palestinian Territories (West Bank) laid by the Jordanian military prior to the 1967 war, which impact upon the lives of Palestinian civilians today. This project is contributing, together with three other donors (United States, New Zealand, United Kingdom) to clearance of seven minefields between September 2016 and August 2018, using equipment, infrastructure and a management team already in place. The programme is working under the coordination of the Israeli National Mine Action Authority (INMAA), and the Palestinian Mine Action Authority (PMAC).

The seven minefields are on predominantly agricultural land which, once cleared, will reduce violence against citizens, and contribute to the safety and economic security of the landowners and surrounding communities. 419 people will benefit directly and 58,915 benefit indirectly from land released. Land released and put back into productive use will lead to socio-economic and livelihood improvements; 76% of land released will be for agriculture, 24% for renovation of infrastructure.

name.narrative: Um Daraj, Hebron District, West Bank.

description.narrative: Very dry and eroded desert upland, including wadis, steep rocky gradients and flat mesa tops; minefield was laid to protect a hilltop position, so clearance undertaken on approach track, on steep, stony slopes and in shallow depressions at lower levels. Area now falls within an Israeli military firing range, and humanitarian clearance supports local Bedu pastoral families who graze their flocks of sheep and goats regularly across the land.

activity-description.narrative: Manual and mechanical mine / UXO clearance.

sector.narrative: Manual and mechanical mine / UXO clearance of the full task polygon to effect 100% land release.

Enhanced resilience: Percentage of direct beneficiaries surveyed reporting improved livelihoods

description.narrative: This outcome corresponds to the Netherlands' Government Strategic Rule of Law Policy Goal 4: 'Socio-economic reconstruction'

title.narrative: Percentage of direct beneficiaries surveyed reporting improved livelihoods

comment.narrative: Baseline conducted by HALO in 2013, updated in 2014 and in 2016 as part of detailed non technical survey (NTS) of each task and surrounding community. Land owners were interviewed to determine perceptions of threat as a result of the presence of the mines, and the security and potential socio-economic benefit likely to derive from the clearance activity.

title.narrative: Enhanced resilience: Number of Direct Beneficiaries of Land Release

description.narrative: This outcome corresponds to the Netherlands' Government Strategic Rule of Law Policy Goal 4: 'Socio-economic reconstruction'

title.narrative: Number of Direct Beneficiaries of Land Release

description.narrative: The anticipated target has been set based on on previous pre-clearance beneficiary surveys in other regions of the country.

comment.narrative: The seven remaining Jordanian laid minefields in the West Bank are each located close to or in among Palestinian communities. While existence of the minefields is known to landowners and nearby Palestinian community members, the sites are poorly fenced and marked, and people frequently stray on to the contaminated ground. Although no database exists and some information is only anecdotal, there has been a small but steady number of explosive incidents resulting in injury and death to adults, children and animals for fifty years (1967 - 2017). The goal of removing the threat posed to Palestinian civilians will be achieved through completon of mine clearance.

The area in square metres cleared through the removal and/or destruction of all specified mine and ERW hazards to a pre-determined depth, using manual or mechanical assets.

comment.narrative: 137m2-Manual in Yabad, 823m2 Mech in Arraba. On May 28th operations were suspended since the external QA contract was not renewed due to lack of PMWRA funding.

description.narrative: The number of UXO which have been located and susequently rendered safe or destroyed.

comment.narrative: During 2017 HALO in the West Bank completed and returned three tasks, Um Daraj (Q1), Surif (Q3), Deir Abu-Da'if (Q4). During Q5, winter 2017/18, HALO cleared in Jenin District only manual sections. HALO completed the manual section in Arraba and starred the manual section in Qabatiya. These two areas will be returned to the communities following the completion of mechanical clearance

In Yabad, HALO cleared only the manual segment. The completed plot has not been handed back to the community yet. It is planned to return to Yabad in October to carry on further manual and mech clearance.
